sn4.18:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans near the brahmin village of Pañcasālā.
sn4.18:1.2: Now at that time in Pañcasālā the young women were taking care of guests.
sn4.18:1.3: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Pañcasālā for alms.
sn4.18:1.4: Now at that time Māra had possessed the brahmins and householders of Pañcasālā, so that they thought,
sn4.18:1.5: “Don’t let the ascetic Gotama get any alms!”
sn4.18:2.1: Then the Buddha left the village with his bowl as clean-washed as it was when he entered for alms.
sn4.18:2.2: Then Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha and said to him,
sn4.18:2.3: “Well, ascetic, did you get any alms?”
sn4.18:2.4: “Wicked One, did you make sure I didn’t get any alms?”
sn4.18:2.5: “Well then, sir, let the Buddha enter Pañcasālā a second time for alms.
sn4.18:2.6: I’ll make sure you get alms.”
sn4.18:3.3: Wicked One, do you imagine that
sn4.18:4.1: Let us live so very happily,
sn4.18:4.4: like the gods of streaming radiance.”
sn4.18:5.1: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
